medium_description_en: Calculates pressure needed to overcome elastic resistance to ventilation.
before_use: Launched during COVID-19 crisis. COVID-19 Resource Center.
search_abbreviation_en: Static Compliance (Cstat) Calculation, cstat calculation, cstat, static compliance, compliance, ventilation pressure, lung compliance, ventilation, ventilator, ventilator pressure, elastic resistance, resistance, lung resistance, lung pressure, covid19, covid-19, covid 19, covid, coronavirus

seo.meta_description_en: The Static Compliance (Cstat) Calculation calculates pressure needed to overcome elastic resistance to ventilation.
seo.keywords_en: Static Compliance (Cstat) Calculation, cstat calculation, cstat, static compliance, compliance, ventilation pressure, lung compliance, ventilation, ventilator, ventilator pressure, elastic resistance, resistance, lung resistance, lung pressure, ventilator setting, ventilator settings, ventilation setting, ventilation settings, SCAP, MuLBSTA, SMART-COP, covid19, covid-19, covid 19, covid, coronavirus

how_to_use.use_case_en: Pplat is measured before exhalation (end of inhalation) by using an inspiratory hold maneuver. Airflow is briefly "held", eliminating the effects of airway resistance.
how_to_use.pearls_pitfalls_en: Cstat (static compliance) is static (during an inspiratory hold, where no gas flow is taking place), and should not be confused with Cdyn (dynamic compliance), calculated during gas flow.
how_to_use.why_use_en:
• Static lung compliance is change in volume for any applied pressure given.

  • Work of breathing is largely determined by lung compliance, and compliance can be important in monitoring disease progression, particularly in critical patients on mechanical ventilation in the ICU.

  • Low lung compliance suggests "stiffness" - seen in fibrotic conditions, for example.

  • High lung compliance suggests pliability - seen in conditions like emphysema, for example.

  • ARDS in particular causes decreased lung compliance by alveolar collapse and decreased surfactant activity; part of the treatment of severe ARDS involves attempting to improve lung compliance (proning, neuromuscular blockade, etc).

next_steps.advice_en: In cases of worsening or poor lung compliance (in particular ARDS), methods to improve pulmonary compliance may be beneficial; improving compliance often improves plateau pressures and oxygenation.

about.formula_en: Static lung compliance (Cstat), mL/cm H2O = Corrected/delivered tidal volume (ΔV), mL / (Plateau pressure (Pplat), cm H2O – PEEP, cm H2O)
about.more_info_en:
Interpretation:

Normal static lung compliance is 50-100 mL/cm H2O.

Original/Primary Reference.text: Marshall R. The physical properties of the lungs in relation to the subdivisions of lung volume. Clin Sci. 1957;16(3):507-15.

Validation.text: Fry DL, Hyatt RE. Pulmonary mechanics. A unified analysis of the relationship between pressure, volume and gasflow in the lungs of normal and diseased human subjects. Am J Med. 1960;29:672-89.

expert_name.description: Graham Walker, MD, is an emergency physician practicing in San Francisco, California. Dr. Walker attended medical school at the Stanford University School of Medicine and then trained in emergency medicine at St. Luke’s-Roosevelt Hospital Center in New York City, where he was Chief Resident. He returned to the west coast as a Medical Simulation fellow and attending in Stanford’s emergency department. More relevant, of course, is that Dr. Walker is the creator and developer of MDCalc and remains active in content and calculator development, along with our many other endeavors as President of MD Aware, LLC (MDCalc’s parent company).
expert_name.name: Graham Walker, MD

creator_info.about_en: Robert Marshall, MD, was a physician and researcher in the department of physiology and pharmacology at the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia. Dr. Marshall’s primary research is focused on the physical properties of lungs and pulmonary mechanics.
